data.title: Black Diamond Group Limited raises dividend by 28.6% to CAD 0.045
data.description:
• Black Diamond Group Limited (BDI:CA) declares CAD 0.045/share quarterly dividend, 28.6% increase from prior dividend of CAD 0.035.
  • Payable Jan. 15; for shareholders of record Dec. 31; ex-div Dec. 31.
  • See BDI:CA Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.

data.title: Wall Street rallies higher on Amazon and Apple earnings
data.description:
Wall Street moved higher on Friday with the major indexes advancing as upbeat earnings from big tech companies fueled investor optimism.

Rising the most on the session was the tech focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) which was last up 0.9%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) was in the green by 0.4%, and the blue-chip Dow (DJI) climbed up 0.1%.

From a sector point of view, five of the 11 S&P segments advanced with Consumer Discretionary leading the way. At the other end of the spectrum, the Materials space has suffered the most on the session so far.

U.S. Treasury yields ticked lower with the longer-end U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) falling 1 basis point to 4.08% and the shorter-end U.S. 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) moved down by 1 basis point to 3.60%.

"Indeed, just as the tech mood had soured yesterday, this morning that has mostly turned around following results from Apple and Amazon after the closing bell," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said.

Amazon (AMZN) soared 11.3% after it topped Q3 estimates with better-than-expected net sales, profits, and subscription revenues, and more importantly. It also delivered a beat on the company’s AWS, all of which offset compressed margins.

Apple (AAPL) traded near even after the tech giant reported fiscal fourth-quarter results that topped estimates.

On political news, the U.S. States reportedly cancelled a planned Budapest summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russia's firm stance on hardline demands regarding Ukraine.

data.title: JPMorgan takes equity stake in TXSE as part of second capital raise
data.description:
JPMorgan Chase (JPM) made an equity investment in Texas Stock Exchange Group ("TXSE") as part of the TXSE's second-round capital raise ahead of its planned launch in Q1 2026, the company said on Friday.

As part of JPMorgan's (JPM) investment, the bank will join TXSE Group's board of directors as an observer. Combined with previous fundraising, TXSE has raised more than $250M. 

Bloomberg News reported that the TXSE raised ~$90M from a group of investors in the latest capital raise. In September 2024, the company said it had raised $135M. The exchange had raised $120M in early 2024, with BlackRock (BLK) and Citadel Securities participating.

"Our strong capital position validates our mission to bring increased competition to the U.S. capital markets," said James H Lee, founder and CEO of TXSE Group. "The Texas Stock Exchange's focus on alignment and transparency for issuers will alter the trajectory of our public markets and help establish Texas as a new global leader in capital markets."

Charles Schwab (SCHW) is another prominent investor in the exchange. In total, 82 financial institutions and business leaders have invested in TXSE Group.

data.title: Tego Cyber rebrands to VigilAigent Corp
data.description:
• Tego Cyber (TGCB) has officially changed its name to VigilAigent Corp, effective immediately.
  • The rebranding follows the launch of the VigilAigent Managed Security Services platform earlier this year.
  • The new identity reflects the company’s evolution into an Agentic AI-powered cybersecurity organization.
  • The VigilAigent platform combines Virtual Aigents (AI operatives) and Special Aigents (human SOC experts) for adaptive, autonomous defense.
  • The company will introduce a new ticker symbol.

data.title: Rithm Property Trust signals potential liquidation or recapitalization amid $5.30 book value and $2.40 stock price gap
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Rithm Property Trust Inc. (RPT) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Michael Nierenberg opened by stating, "when we took over this company last June, we stabilized the company, which at that time, I think was losing in and around $10 million a quarter. Today, the company essentially is flat when you take into account earnings and we're still paying a $0.06 dividend." He emphasized the liquidation of residential assets and the addition of commercial real estate floaters, describing these as "higher yielding top part of the capital stack with some reasonable yield."
  • Nierenberg highlighted options for the company: "we can recap the vehicle with an offering of equity associated with a pool of assets... we could explore some kind of liquidation of the company... Or three is, stay the course."
  • He stated, "with book value at $5.30 and the stock trading at $2.40-odd, clearly, there's a huge value play for equity investors in this."
  • The CEO detailed progress on developing a direct lending business, referencing partnerships with Genesis and the company's growth in construction loans: "we grew a company that was doing $1.7 billion in production. Today, we're going to -- this year, we'll probably do north of $5 billion."
  • Nierenberg reiterated, "we're not going to leave this thing outstanding for the sake of leaving a company outstanding. We need to either figure out a way to grow it or at some point, we'll likely think about an auction process for the company and realize what I think is going to be true book value."
  • He noted the company has "in and around $100 million of cash. The company has about $300 million in total equity. And the pipelines look great. The portfolio is about $308 million today."
  • CFO Nick Santoro was not directly quoted in the transcript section provided.

Outlook

  • Management discussed three possible paths: recapitalization, liquidation, or continued operations with a focus on growth, but stated, "we're not going to just stay the course and leave something outstanding for the sake of leaving something outstanding."
  • The CEO expressed optimism for the direct lending business and future deals, but stressed the need for execution: "we got to -- quite frankly, we have to execute on that plan."
  • On the Paramount acquisition, Nierenberg said, "one of the questions we got on yesterday's call, is it something that we consider adding some Paramount to the -- adding to the Rithm Property Trust and the answer, what I said was yes."
  • There was no explicit financial guidance or updated earnings targets provided for future quarters in the transcript.

Financial Results

  • Nierenberg described results as "effectively, the company was flat quarter-over-quarter, still maintained a $0.06 dividend. Cash and cash equivalents on balance sheet at the end of the quarter, $81 million and total equity is $292 million."
  • The company originated a $21 million loan on a grocery-anchored retail center outside Seattle, with an expected yield in the "mid-teens."
  • No other explicit financial figures, EPS, or revenue data were stated for the quarter.

Q&A

  • William Catherwood, BTIG, LLC: Asked about the current pool of loans in closing and the company's direction. Nierenberg responded, "there's a couple of things here. One is I brought up the Paramount deal. That's a big deal. I mean there's $6.60 on 13 million square feet... We have passed on what I would say, more of and some of this is, as you think about the mayoral election here... we're not going to do rent-stabilized loans in New York City right now."
  • Catherwood: Asked about the Paramount transaction and RPT's potential position. Nierenberg clarified, "they had some legacy funds. I would assume for purposes of this discussion, there's nothing to do with Rithm Property Trust and those funds. It would likely be a position that would be pari passu alongside Rithm, the parent."
  • Catherwood: Asked about discount to book value and credit risks across the sector. Nierenberg said, "a lot of the legacy commercial real estate REITs were still saddled with... underwater loans that need to get worked out. We do not have any of those here at our firm."
  • Craig Kucera, Lucid Capital Markets: Asked about economics of Paramount for RPT. Nierenberg said, "the Paramount deal is more equity based... a $50 million equity check gives you about a 2x MOIC on that $50 million and a 20-plus percent return based on our assumptions."
  • Kucera: Inquired about Rithm Capital deploying capital into RPT. Nierenberg responded, "I think to keep it clean, we'd prefer to do something that's not like that, but I don't know yet just to where we ultimately go."
  • Kucera: Asked about new third-party partners for RPC. Nierenberg said, "this deal has opened up conversations that truly we wouldn't have had 6 months ago."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts adopted a probing and skeptical tone, frequently focusing on the discount to book value, capital deployment plans, and potential for new transactions. Their questions often pressed for specifics on execution and risk, particularly regarding the Paramount deal and sector-wide credit concerns.
  • Management maintained an optimistic but pragmatic tone, emphasizing clean balance sheets and strategic optionality. In prepared remarks, Nierenberg was direct about possible strategic shifts. In Q&A, he showed confidence but occasionally hedged, saying, "I think to keep it clean, we'd prefer to do something that's not like that, but I don't know yet just to where we ultimately go."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone was more focused on strategic alternatives, while analysts were more pointed regarding risks and value realization.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter introduced more explicit discussion of company-altering moves, including liquidation or recapitalization, compared to the previous quarter’s emphasis on pipeline growth and capital deployment.
  • The previous quarter highlighted a robust pipeline and intent to avoid equity dilution, while the current call focused more on strategic options in light of persistent stock price discounts and capital constraints.
  • Analyst questions in the current quarter sharpened focus on execution risks, sector-wide credit concerns, and the mispricing of equity, reflecting increased market skepticism.
  • Management’s confidence in the direct lending platform and opportunistic nature of the portfolio was a recurring theme, but this quarter added a sense of urgency regarding potential major transactions.

Risks and Concerns

  • Nierenberg identified sector-wide risks, stating, "a lot of the legacy commercial real estate REITs were still saddled with... underwater loans that need to get worked out. We do not have any of those here."
  • He emphasized the company’s clean balance sheet and lack of legacy issues but acknowledged, "the thing is you need capital to grow. And with the stock trading at whatever, 50-odd percent of book, it's very difficult."
  • Analysts raised concerns about persistent equity mispricing, capital deployment effectiveness, and execution risks tied to potential major transactions like Paramount.

Final Takeaway

Rithm Property Trust management underscored the company’s clean balance sheet, ongoing dividend, and opportunistic strategy, while openly considering significant moves such as recapitalization or liquidation in response to the persistent gap between book value and share price. The call highlighted a focus on growth through direct lending and select asset acquisitions, with management stressing that all options remain under review to maximize shareholder value and address capital constraints.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: KeyBanc cuts rating on Comcast over bleak picture for broadband growth
data.description:
KeyBanc Capital Markets lowered its investment rating on Comcast (CMCSA) to "sector weight" from "overweight," citing a lack of catalysts following the company's third-quarter results.

The research firm said while broadband and mobile net additions were better than expected in Q3, it underappreciated the investment needed to achieve those results. It also noted that shareholder returns in terms of buyback are likely to decline going forward due to the investments for connectivity and platforms division, ramping NBA costs, and Versant spinoff.

KeyBanc pointed out that Comcast's broadband penetration rate has fallen for 14 consecutive quarters, and hence they need to see signs of stabilization before becoming more constructive on the company.

"Competitive concerns in broadband are likely to continue for the foreseeable future as telecom providers ramp fiber and FWA offerings over the next several years, where it's uncertain if and when Comcast will return to broadband subscriber growth," the research firm said in its analysis dated October 30.

"While CMCSA is inexpensive ... we think it's clearly trading there for a reason, as competitive concerns are elevated and investment is needed to hopefully return CMCSA to competitive positioning," KeyBanc said.

The research firm currently does not have a price target for CMCSA.

data.title: November and December could add more than 4% to the S&P 500 – analyst
data.description:
When the S&P 500 (SP500) has gained more than 15% by October’s close year-to-date, the months of November and December combined tend to extend the rally, according to Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at Carson Group.

The S&P 500 (SP500) is currently 16.6% year-to-date. Carson Investment Research found that when the index gains more than 15% by the end of October, in 20 out of 21 years – with the exception of 2021 – the S&P 500 ends an extra 4.7% higher on average.

 

 

 

In 2024, even when at the end of December the S&P 500 (SP500) was -2.5%, the index still ended 3.1% for the months of November and December combined.

In 2019, the months of November and December added an extra 6.4% to the index, as at the end of October the index yielded 21.2%.

S&P-tracking ETFs: (SPY), (VOO), (IVV), (RSP), (SSO), (UPRO), (SH), (SDS), (SPXU)

data.title: LyondellBasell targets $1.1B in savings by 2026 amid signs of market recovery
data.description:
LyondellBasell Industries (LYB) announced Friday that it remains on pace to achieve $1.1 billion in cost reductions by 2026, crediting stronger demand trends and tight cost control for a quarterly performance that exceeded Wall Street forecasts.

The upbeat report pushed shares as much as 5.3% higher in trading, a sign of easing investor worries over soft demand and higher input costs, especially in Europe.

The Houston-based chemicals producer said its “cash improvement” initiative, introduced earlier this year, is expected to generate about $600 million in additional cash flow next year.

Profitability improved notably in its olefins and polyolefins Americas segment, helped by wider olefins margins and increased polyethylene sales following maintenance turnarounds at Texas plants. Management noted early signs of recovery in polyolefins demand, with U.S. polyethylene volumes rebounding after two sluggish years and European volumes climbing roughly 3% year-to-date.

For the third quarter, the company reported a net loss of $890 million, or $2.77 a share, compared with a profit of $573 million a year earlier. Results included about $1.2 billion in non-cash asset impairments and restructuring charges, mostly tied to its European operations. LyondellBasell (LYB) said ongoing regulatory pressures in Europe have prompted it and other producers to streamline operations and trim costs.

As part of a broader portfolio overhaul, the company has secured approval to sell four European assets and plans short maintenance shutdowns at plants in Germany and Texas to align with market conditions.

Looking ahead, management warned that typical seasonal softness and higher feedstock prices could compress margins in the fourth quarter. Still, the company expects recent capacity reductions in China, Japan, South Korea and Europe to help restore global supply balance.

On an adjusted basis, earnings were $1.01 a share, topping the analyst consensus of $0.80 compiled by S&P Global Intelligence.
